Our residents will also warmly receive Work for the Dole being made compulsory for 25- to 34-year-olds who have been in receipt of unemployment benefits for 12 months or more. At last those people who have been desperately seeking ways to join the work force through the Work for the Dole projects will be allowed in. Such is the success of the Work for the Dole program, based on our SEALâShoalhaven Earning a Livingâprogram, that we actually have people queued up to join. Forty-two per cent of those participants go on to get a job, well above the national average of 32 per cent, which is well above Labor's capital intensive so-called labour market programs.

This budget also extends measures to combat social security fraud which have reflected enormous savings to date so that we might better direct resources to those who really need them. As Australians, we choose to look after our neighbours and provide assistance when they can no longer look after themselves. That is what these measures are for: to ensure that people really are trying to help themselves. No longer will we tolerate those who are, by deceit, taking from those who are in need. The extension of respite support for carers of young people with disabilities and for carers of people with dementia and other cognitive or behavioural disabilities is very welcome. In Gilmore, as in most other places, carers do the bulk of looking after people with special needs. Extra respite care can go some way towards meeting everybody's needs so they can function better in the long term. I applaud the government for recognising such need through the extra funding from this budget.

The budget contains an extra $1 billion over four years to help homeless people and those at risk of homelessness. I sometimes pause and wonder why an electorate with so many empty houses would have so many homeless people and so few houses for rent. Of course Gilmore is a holiday destination and most of the so-called empty houses are holiday houses, which do regularly have people in them for short periods of time. We need facilities for crisis, medium- and long-term accommodation for a range of people who become homeless for many different reasons. And we need it in Gilmore; we do not need it in the Illawarra. By that I mean the Southern Highlands, Kiama and the Shoalhaven. Just today I received advice that we are a community in high need of service after 13 years of govern ment by Labor. I will do all I can to see that these services and funds are given to Gilmore.

Whilst there is no reason to crow about being recognised, the fact remains that, in order to help ourselves, we need the full support of this government and the state government, including the member for the South Coast. We need a reversal of decisions by the state government such as its demonstrated lack of support. We want to provide quality support for people who want to take control of their lives for the better in the long term. We want to instil the family values of love, honour and respect without trapping people in dysfunctional family situations. The Australian Labor Party have shown their complete lack of vision for our area. They have none. During the three years the federal coalition has been in governmentâjust one term and some monthsâas the federal member for Gilmore I have attracted $148.8 million for infrastructure and projects, $126 million for investment and jobs, $538,000 for aged care, $33,000 for the veterans, $8.53 million for youth and education, $2.64 million for community, families and security and $1.9 million for the environment.

The people of Gilmore are looking for vision and government dollars and to see priorities made being kept. This government is helping to provide that vision through the funding of projects such as main road 92, the university for Nowra due to open in 2000, the ethanol trial plant, the new navy helicopter contract, the Nowra Christian School, the Shoalhaven Anglican School, St Johns High School, Nowra TAFE, Ulladulla TAFE and Moss Vale TAFE, and Landcare-Dunecare projects at Nowra, Berry, Kangaroo Valley, Jervis Bay, Cudmirrah, Lake Conjola, Narrawallee, Kiama, Swan Haven, Shoalhaven Heads, Minnamurra, Vincentia, Termeil, Tabourie Lake and Burrill Lake. But there is much more to be done.

This speech should serve as both a thank you and a warning to the governmentâa thank you on behalf of the local residents for your commitment to our needs and a warning to be prepared for me to be on your doorstep seeking more support for local projects. These projects will include: the upgrade of the Princes Highway, particularly around Kiama, the Southern Highlands university, the Ulladulla boat harbour, the Jervis Bay marina, the Ulladulla fishing museum, a bushfire centre of excellence, the Solar Sailor research and development for further solar powered craft, the academy of music, the arts centre in the Shoalhaven, more focus on oceanography and aquaculture, more defence facilities and employment opportunities at Albatross and Creswell and also further upgrading of the facilities for tourism. All these things are part of the Gilmore vision: that is, creating more investment and employment opportunities through the development of infrastructure and through the provision of more support for families and the local environment. That vision goes into the next centuryâjust as this government has brought down a budget, a budget surplus and a tax reform package for the new millennium.

In closing, I would like to draw to the attention of the House the important work being done by many of its staff. With more than 3,000 people working here during sitting weeks, the frenetic pace of budget week has brought home just how important each and every cog in the workings of this House isâeveryone from cleaning staff to ground keepers, catering, administration and security. They do a fantastic job in keeping this House in order.

In particular, I would like to pay tribute to the staff of the Information and Research Service of the Parliamentary Library. They do a tremendous job and provide an invaluable service providing members, senators and their staff with information, quickly, comprehensively and always willingly. Not only do they help boost the productivity of an electorate office, but through their work they have also improved the quality of service that my office provides to the constituents of Gilmore. Thank you to Dr June Verrier and her team for their assistance and the support they provide for all members of this House.

In conclusion, Mr Speaker, may I say that this budget is responsible and pragmatic and provides a solid basis from which all Australians, particularly the residents of Gilmore, can work to help themselves and their community. It is a far cry from what those opposite are saying. I seem to recall those opposite criticising the very budget which provided these measures for Gilmore. They criticised our hospital rebate scheme, our Work for the Dole programs, our tax reform package and the GST, and the funding for non-government schools. In fact, they are very good at criticising, but what have they offered in return? I will tell you what they have offeredâfear campaigns, put-down and derision. Those opposite who aspire to government do not even bother offering serious policy options. The only one among them who did now occupies a place on the back bench.

Scaremongering is what the Labor Party is good at, but that is not the sort of skill that a responsible government uses to run a country. That is why the people of Gilmore know that they cannot trust the scaremongering of the opposition and certainly not the state government on its commitments prior to the last state election on Main Road 92.
Debate interrupted.

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Kaiser, Master Jed: Australian Taxation Office

talk.start.para: âAt a time when this government is preoccupied with tax reform, at a time when it argues that tax reform is in the interests of the nation, I have been overwhelmed by the inequity that exists in the tax system and overwhelmed by the Treasurer's failure to even answer a letter than I have sent to him in relation to one particular constituent within Shortland who has been treated very poorly by the tax system. This government believes that the only tax reform Australia needs is a GST, a regressive 1950s style tax that will tax every Australian every day from birth to death.
âThat's not true at all.

âI suggest the members on the other side of the House actually listen to the case I am about to share with them tonight, because it could also affect constituents within their own electorate. I argue that tax reform is more than a GST. Nothing could demonstrate more graphically to me the inequity that exists in our tax system than the plight of young Jed Kaiser. Jed Kaiser is a three-year-old who lives in my electorate of Shortland. Jed's father was tragically killed on 14 November 1996 in the Gretley coal mine disaster. It was a tragedy that left a young boy without a father, a young woman without a husband and a family that has to now scrape and struggle to survive.

speech.para: Jed was awarded $75,000 lump sum compensation by the New South Wales WorkCover Authority. You might think that that is a lot of money, but $75,000 does nothing to replace the loss of a father for a young three-year-old or, as he was then, just a baby. This money has been invested with the Public Trustee and cannot be touched until Jed turns 18 years of age, except for educational needs. He also receives $150 a fortnight from coal mine insurance, a paltry amount when you think what he has lost and what his future is now, in comparison to what it was when his father was alive. Last year, his mother, Lisa, had a taxable income of $9,058. This is the money that this family has to survive on after losing their main breadwinner.

Jed was overwhelmed in January when he received a tax bill for $1,600. Jed and his mother do not have money to pay this tax bill. They are very poor. They struggle for every little bit of luxury, every bit of food that they put on the table. But the tax office has now threatened to access that $1,600 by going in and taking the money from the Public Trustee funds. Jed cannot access that money, except for educational expenses, but the Australian Taxation Office can take the money that has been put in trust for Jed to replace the loss of his father and to at least give him some hope for the future.

This is disgusting, particularly when at the same time that Jed was served with this $1,600 tax bill, Kerry Packer's personal income tax bill was assessed as being $30. On one hand we have a young boy who has lost his father; on the other hand we have the richest man in Australia paying $30 tax. It is just not on. It is very inequitable. Young Jed's situation is grossly unfair, but the Treasurer cannot even answer my letter.

The University of Newcastle has taken up and has been supporting Jed in his battle for fairness. He is not a wealthy three-year-old whose father has set up a trust to avoid tax; he is a young boy who has suffered the greatest loss any young person could suffer. Jed does not have a father and that is why he was awarded the $75,000. Fairness in our tax system is not a GST. Fairness is making sure that three-year-olds who have lost their father do not have to pay tax on money they cannot even use.

talk.start.para: âI would like to take the opportunity tonight to update the parliament and the Australian community on the efforts that are being made in my electorate in Mangrove Mountain to eradicate the outbreak of Newcastle disease which occurred there on 1 April, when it was first identified. This outbreak of Newcastle disease is an endemic strain which has unfortunately mutated from a non-virulent form to a virulent form. The only way to eradicate it, on advice, was to destroy all the livestock and birds in the area. It involved the destruction of 1,928,020 chickens on the mountain, fully de-stocking 32 farms. It also involved the destruction of backyard flocks of chickens and other pets. This was very traumatic to the community of Mangrove Mountain. It was not just backyard chooks, it was things like peacocks, ostriches, canaries and budgerigars, pets that have been in the family for many years, children's pets. It is, Mr Speaker, a tragedy, a natural disaster of immense proportions.

speech.para: The community of Mangrove Mountain have rallied to the cause. They understand it is in the national interest to ensure that this disease is controlled within the control area of Mangrove Mountain. I am pleased to report to the parliament that the federal government, following my representations, provided some ex gratia payments and set up a system where those farmers who are without income can receive support benefits for the next three months. It must be remembered that all of the stock in their chicken sheds was destroyed. It means they will have no income and no production for an unknown timeâit will be at least three months and possibly six months. As I said to the Prime Minister when I was seeking support, if it had been a flood or a fire that devastated this community all of Australia would have been rushing to help the Mangrove Mountain community, but because it was a disease outbreakâsomething we had not experienced to this extent anywhere Australiaâthe impact was not readily seen by the rest of Australia. The impact is just as serious if not more serious than a flood or a fire because the impact will go on for so long. I am very pleased the federal government was able to provide that support.

In addition, there has been a tremendous effort on the part of many volunteers in the Mangrove Mountain area to assist with monitoring and to assist the support staffâthey include people from the Rural Fire Service, the State Emergency Service, St John Ambulance, the Central Coast Coastal Patrol, Gosford City Council, the CWA, the RSPCA and WIRES. Even the Queensland Fire and Rescue Association travelled down from Queensland to assist the volunteersâremember that at that time many of our emergency service volunteers were involved in the clean up of the hail damage in Sydney so it was difficult to provide enough volunteers. Staff from the New South Wales agriculture department had control of the clean up efforts. I hesitate to mention groups because I know I will have forgotten some other groups and people who have assisted over the last couple of months in the efforts to clean up this disease.

Comments have been made by people that there are still many questions to be answered, and that is true. The community of Mangrove Mountain deserves answers as to where this disease came from, how it mutated, what precautions can be taken for the future and whether the federal government or the New South Wales government could have done anything better in our assistance to the farmers to eradicate this virus in the Mangrove Mountain area. I encourage the federal government and the state government to have an inquiry at the completion of this eradication process to ensure that the efforts we have made are the best available. If things can be done betterâshould this ever occur againâwe need to ensure that that will be done. Also, the residents of Mangrove Mountain deserve to have a full inquiry to answer their concerns.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to focus on the importance of multiculturalism to my electorate of Chisholm and the Australian community generally. As all members would be aware, Australia's migration program began in earnest with the dismantling of the White Australia Policy after World War II and its replacement with a non-discriminatory program of migrant intake. In fact, some 5.7 million migrants have settled in Australia since 1945. Today, nearly one in four of Australia's 18.6 million people were born overseas. The benefits of this largely bipartisan program have been well documented. Unfortunately, in the past few years the program has had its detractors as well, but I do not wish to dwell on that tonight. I encourage this parliament to continue robust support of migration but would also like to explain some of the problems within the system that need to be rectified.

speech.para: In my seat of Chisholm over 30 per cent of residents were born overseas. One of the great joys of my job is visiting the various ethnic communities in Chisholmâbe it the Chinese and Vietnamese restaurateurs in Box Hill, the dynamic and well organised Italian and Greek senior citizens clubs in Clayton and Oakleigh or the emerging population of Sri Lankans in Mount Waverley. It is an area thriving from the benefits of mass migration. When asked to list the benefits of multiculturalism it is easy to reel them offânew customs, new religions, new music, dance and food and the obvious economic advantages of increased commerce and trade opportunities. I believe the new customs that have come with the post war migration program have greatly enhanced our civic life and are wonderful additions to the local culture of Chisholm.

One of the most underrated benefits of multiculturalism is the different perspective that migrants bring. It is my belief that the best education we can give to our children is to encourage them to learn from each other. Migrants bring with them a wealth of traditions, skills and experiences. Listening to stories from migrants reminds all Australians of how truly lucky we are and safeguards us from becoming too inward looking due to our physical isolation. However, if we are to support a strong migration policy, there are a number of things we need to do as a nation. Firstly, we must continue to administer a humanitarian program that allows for family reunions and, secondly, we need to provide the infrastructure to enable migrants to acclimatise to the new culture. Sadly, I would have to say that the government is failing on both counts and there is proof of that in my own electorate.

The government has gutted the family migration stream, and in particular the parents migration stream by slashing it to a mere 500 places and effectively ensuring that thousands of people will never be reunited with their parents. Many local migrants have come to my office in the past few months seeking residency for their parents only to be told that they must join a waiting listânow at over 20,000âthat is never likely to be cleared. This leaves many migrants with the unpalatable choice of finding the money to emigrate, fly home for a visit or never see their parents again. In relation to my second point, newly arrived migrants need considerable support to adapt to their new home and they encounter adjustment problems such as language difficulties, dealing with bureaucracy and gaining employment. In addition to this they obviously need ongoing support in light of the fact that many migrants come here jaded from unpleasant experiences at home and without their network of friends and family.

There is a range of organisations in my community that provide this sort of infrastructure: the Communities Council on Ethnic Issues (Eastern Region), the Oakleigh Migrant Resource Centre and the Chinese Community Council of Social Services. Sadly, there are never enough funds to ensure they deliver their services properly. Chisholm has an ever-growing number of migrants settling in the area, particularly in the Box Hill end. As you can imagine, it was a huge surprise to me when the Migrant Information Centre, initially earmarked for Box Hill, was opened in Mitcham. This is despite the fact the City of Whitehorse, which encapsulates Box Hill, has the third-highest number of residents of a non-English speaking background out of the eight eastern municipalities. The City of Maroondah, in which Mitcham is located, only ranks seventh.

In addition, Box Hill is the transport hub of the east, serviced by bus, train and tram. It is home to numerous servicesâsuch as Centrelink, the tax office, Human Services and AMESâand is a thriving shopping centre. This makes Box Hill an ideal location for the service. This extremely puzzling decision has been shrouded in controversy; the disproportionately high salary of the centre's CEO and the contentious appointment of the member for Deakin to the board of directors are both examples of this. To add further insult to injury, Box Hill's immigration office will now be closed on 25 June. Whilst the reason given for the closure was the need to rationalise services, it appears no consideration was given to the inconvenience to clients of moving the facility, not to mention the lack of logic in moving it away from amongst its clientele.

In conclusion, I believe it is crucial that Australia continues to pursue a non-discriminatory immigration program in a broader framework of a targeted population policy. However, ethnic diversity comes with a price tag. To continue to be a choice destination for migrants looking to resettle, we must provide sufficient services that offer face-to-face contact for people not fluent in English. Support services like those needed for the booming migrant population in my electorate must be located in sensible locations. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I want to argue the cause against the implementation of legalised heroin shooting galleries, in New South Wales or anywhere else. I am indebted to Ross Goodridge, barrister-at-law, for drawing to my attention some of the implications that legalised heroin shooting galleries would create in any community. Some of the questions that Ross Goodridge asks are as follows: where would the shooting galleries be? Would they have to have police approval for the siting or zoning? Would there be objections taken from local residents and would there be a change in the zoning that would allow galleries to be established? If the answer is no for the establishment of a gallery and that there should be discouragement of police supervising the selling of drugs in the vicinity, does that mean the lack of police supervision will encourage further crime in that area? If doctors are to supervise the purchase and distribution of drugs in close proximity to a gallery, will that mean that the police turn a blind eye to the distributors and pushers of drugs?

speech.para: The police have to have a role in this process, and whether or not they are encouraged to do their duty as far as pushers or sellers are concerned has to be a matter ascertained by the community. Statistics from around the world show that there is a strong correlation between a person being affected by drugs and the occurrence of crime. Does that mean that galleries will encourage prostitution and other related crimes in an area? Is that what a particular community would want? Would the sale of drugs be tolerated in the shooting gallery premises? First of all, the sale of drugs can be anything from sales of large quantities of drugs to a $20 hit and addicts sharing drugs with each other. If no drug selling will be tolerated, how can that be policed? Are addicts expected to drive across the city to Cabramatta, say, and then come back to the centre of Sydney? Will that not occur? How artificial would it be to say to an addict that he must buy his heroin outside the door of a gallery and bring it into the gallery to use it?

Does the government really want to provide premises for the sale of illegal drugs anyway? I notice the government of New South Wales says that it will let other people, not government agencies, conduct the galleries. I have mentioned the consent of neighbours in this process. Would every doctor be entitled to prescribe heroin for an addict? If every doctor were entitled to prescribe heroin, would each doctor be under an obligation to prescribe heroin to any person in need? Could a doctor make a judgment as to whether a person were in need or could a doctor refuse to prescribe heroin for an addict? What about under-age users? Would a doctor be able to say that he could prescribe for an addict at the age of 18 but that an addict under the age of 18 would be denied the drug? How much heroin would each doctor be allowed to prescribe per patientâtwo hits per day, five hits per day or as many as the patient wanted? Would the sharing of Medicare cards, not for the purposes of a prescribed drug but for the purposes of identification, be allowed?

Who would be entitled to have heroin prescribed? Does that mean that every addict has to be identified and for ever after remain classified as an addict? I think this is a hopeless process of assigning people to a permanent life of addiction, and it is just impractical and unworkable. What this nation needs is a program of compassion and care for addicts, the goal of which is to get them out of where they are into something better. To me, it will not work to assign as their only prospect a heroin shooting gallery. I feel Tony Trimingham's pain for the loss of his son but I think he is wrong. I think he is wrong to espouse illegal shooting galleries. I believe that he should resign from the Prime Minister's committee because he cannot share the role of being a person espousing an illegal process, something that really is a terrible blot on the name of Ted Noffs, who would do anything to stop addicts continuing their dreadful habit. What we have seen in Sydney, I believe, should not be promoted by the New South Wales government or anybody associated with the federal government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI stand on an issue of fairness and equity to all Tasmanians and the wider Australian community. It centres on the Bass Strait, the notorious stretch of water separat ing Tasmania from mainland Australiaânotorious among seafarers for its wild and unforgiving reputation, but equally well known, I am sorry to say, as one of the most costly links in Australia's transport chain. Bass Strait is a major impediment to economic self-sufficiency for Tasmania and King Island. It is a barrier to investment, jobs growth and population of our beautiful island state. That is why the campaign continues to have Bass Strait recognised as part of the national highway network, for it to become, if you like, Australia's national `sea highway'.

speech.para: Successive governments have gone part of the way in trying to establish transport equality for Tasmania, but the cost of the movement of freight and passengers across Bass Strait is an issue that will not go away. Accordingly, the government has rightly maintained the long-standing commitment by the Commonwealth to the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme in its recent budget. I also recognise positively the Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme introduced in 1996. This scheme is now the springboard for the National Sea Highway Committee, a Tasmanian based group formed to lobby for transport equity and cheaper fares, to continue their campaign. It is a scheme that gives us a glimpse of the massive benefits that could be achieved by more affordable travel across Bass Strait, which I want to talk about a little later.

But first I have to question the sincerity of this government in regard to what is a vitally important issue to Tasmanians. Firstly, the government appears to have done an about-face on the question of the recognition of Bass Strait as part of the national highway. Back in 1996, coincidentally during an election campaign, the then shadow transport minister, John Sharp, heralded the introduction of the Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme in recognition of the strait as part of the national highway. The Prime Minister himself also acknowledged the great disadvantages facing Tasmania because of Bass Strait. He knew that is what Tasmanians desperately wanted to hear. Yet the former shadow minister's statement now appears to have been a cruel hoax, if we are to believe his successor.

The current Minister for Transport and Regional Services, John Anderson, now says the statement was `incorrect' and that the former minister had made a mistake. Does the Prime Minister agree? The current minister says the Commonwealth is unable to fund travel on Bass Strait as part of the national highway because it would not be allowed under the Australian Land Transport Development Act of 1998. That, I suggest, may be a matter of interpretation and further consideration.

All Australian states except Tasmania are connected by an effective national highway system funded by the Commonwealth. Yet, while the cost of freight and more recently passenger vehicles has been equalised, there is still no equalisation of the cost of passenger ferry travel to and from Tasmania. It has been said that the cost of sea travel between Tasmania and Victoria is the equivalent of imposing a toll on state borders. Imagine the outcry if there were a toll on state borders across mainland Australia. I say again, it is an issue of transport equality for all travellers across the Bass Strait.

But it now also appears to be an issue the current transport minister is trying to sidestep. He does not want to meet the Tasmanian National Sea Highway Committee because he knows there is a very good case for a fully effective national highway to Tasmania. The group is coming to Canberra later this month and wanted to meet the minister. He said no. He does not see the point at this stage. The point is that the minister should at least seek to be better informed. He should not snub this delegation. The federal opposition wants to be better informed and has agreed to meet the group. At the very least the delegation will get a hearing from senior members of this parliament and they are on this side of the House. We are prepared to listen. If he is not aware, I remind the minister that this will be the largest ever bipartisan delegation coming to Canberra from Tasmania to continue the campaign for national highway status. It transcends political boundaries and involves key representatives from business and tourism sectors. Yet the minister cannot find the time to meet members of the delegation. Instead he has handballed the issue to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government.

I again remind the minister that this issue will not go away. It is a proposition worth more investigation. Even with the recently introduced vehicle subsidy, the cost to a family of four for return travel across Bass Strait is in excess of $1,000. Compare the cost for a family of four to travel an equivalent distance on Highway 1. There is no comparison.

The cost of air travel is another impediment to Tasmania's tourist industry and the economy in general. Although air services appear relatively secure, the fares remain high for the great percentage of people coming to and from Tasmania. There is an argument for transport equality for Tasmania, an argument that should be heard. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight in the parliament we have students from Anakie, Batesford, Shelford, Inverleigh, Meredith and Lethbridge primary schools. They have come to see the parliament in action and they need to behave in the gallery or otherwise I might be stood down from the parliament. One of the schools comes from the town of Meredith, which is the home of the very senior politician of Victoria, Sir Henry Bolte. Sir Henry Bolte was a legendary figure in politics in Victoria, as most members opposite would fully understand. He was elected as the temporary leader of the Liberal Party and went on to be the Premier of that state for 17 years. He was a local identity in the town of Meredith and all our students in the gallery would be fully aware of that. They understand that Sir Henry Bolte's name will live forever in the city of Melbourne in that his name is on the City Link bridge.

speech.para: These young students had a mock parliament in Meredith just last week. The classroom was divided into the government and the opposition. They had some eloquent speeches and, unlike the case often in this House, they had some short speeches. The subject before that important parliament was that these students should wear their school uniforms on their trip to Canberra. That resolution was carried by the vote. The Speaker on that occasion, Mr Speaker, was me and I acted impartially, as the member for Wakefield handles the affairs of this House. I followed your very good lead, Mr Speaker, in this particular parliament in Meredith.

The representatives at Meredith understood that they needed to defend the interests of the local community but also be aware of the national interest in terms of the problems facing members in this parliamentâtaxes, pensions, health and defence. They would be aware when we were discussing these matters in this important parliament that Sir Henry Bolte had brought some of these traditions to the city of Meredith and the surrounding district and that he was a great defender of rural Victoria. These young students can understand that long tradition.

The students would be aware that there are changing themes in Meredith and in this part of Corangamite where the wool industry is undergoing considerable changes. The profitability of that industry has declined. However, there is a new industry emerging in plantation of blue gums, Globulas eucalyptus, and these plantations are now developing some other profitable enterprises. Because of the changes in the way these trees are grownâwith the use of ripping, moulding and sprayingâwe can get two crops in 21 years, which are woodchipped to supply the insatiable demand for paper in the Japanese market and throughout the world.
We also have here tonight the teachers, who have come here on a number of occasions: Michael Kinnane, Rob Lamond, Neil Lynch, Jackie Kaiser and Debra Stravanuto. I thank them for being with us.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: âLast Sunday in Launceston, we celebrated National Organ Donation Awareness Day with a thanksgiving and remembrance service conducted by the Australian Kidney Foundation. They are a not-for-profit organisation who have been in existence since 1968. The service allowed us to pause and reflect on the advances which have transformed so many lives in the second half of the 20th century.

speech.para: The development of dialysis and transplant technology has given a second chance at life to people with kidney failure. Just a few decades ago, those lives would have been cut tragically short. Now there is the capacity to extend their life expectancy, which can even outstrip many of their contemporaries. One Tasmanian woman who was just 21 when she suffered terminal kidney failure celebrated this week the 31st anniversary of the transplant operation which has extended her life into her fifties. While that may have been something of an exception at the time, successful transplants have now become commonplace. But all of them, of course, require uncommon generosity in the form of organ donation.

The service provided an opportunity for us to acknowledge the gift of life, to remember those who gave and to give thanks for the lives extended. It was also an opportunity to reflect on the extent of the needs and how we in the wider population can help to address them. Every year, 500,000 Australians consult their doctor with some form of renal infection or associated problem. In total, kidney and urinary tract problems are the cause of 8.4 million visits to the doctor, or 32,000 consultations each weekday. The annual cost to the health system of kidney and urinary tract disease is more than $900 million.

While the goal remains to prevent kidney disease and renal failure, for thousands of Australians it is already too late. There are currently about 3,000 people on the national pooled waiting list for a transplant operation. The waiting time is about three years. Governments now, though, are turning their attention to organ donation.

The Australian health ministers conference at its next meeting in Canberra on 4 August will consider a South Australian proposal to increase the rate of organ donation. The South Australians have reported extraordinary success from a three-year trial. The organ donation rate has increased in the trial to more than double the national average and almost three times the rate in Tasmania. The South Australians have done it by establishing an independent agency to promote awareness of organ donation in the community, recognise and meet the needs of recipients, fully preserve the dignity of donors, and recognise and meet the needs of donor families.

The new approach has shifted the emphasis to supporting families. It ensures a sympathetic and understanding approach to the families of potential donors and offers a full counselling service to provide support and backup. The results are impressive and I support its adoption on a national basis.

Researchers around the world are working on many exciting possibilities in transplant technology. Internationally, biotech companies are working on the developing science of clonal culture tissue engineering and the fabrication of human organs. But in the meantime we need to be conscious of the benefits of the current transplant technology. We need to remember the donors and acknowledge the contribution of their families. We need to give thanks for the gift of life to recipients. We need to promote awareness of the need for future donations to enable this wonderful work to continue. The Australian Kidney Foundation operate very much by donations. I pass on my full support to them and wish them well in what is the awareness week for organ donations.

subdebateinfo.title: Work for the Dole: Hawkesbury Skills

talk.start.para: âI want to place on record the excellent work of the Hawkesbury Skills Work for the Dole program running in my electorate. Hawkesbury Skills have been implementing Work for the Dole since its inception and have an innovative and highly successful program. It provides a valuable combination of work experience, choice, vocational and social development and active pursuit of employment with projects of genuine benefit to the local community. This approach, along with its number of different strands, allows it to cater for the broad diversity of background, skills and interests of its participants and is part of the reason for its success.

speech.para: The current program offers to participants a number of projects. The horticulture, landscaping and environment strand has already completed a number of successful projects and has greatly improved and enhanced the physical amenity and usefulness of several key sites in the local area.

The desktop publishing service provides a valuable resource to non-profit community organisations, producing for them quality promotional material, pamphlets and brochures. The added benefit of this has been the strengthening of links with the local community.

The next step in this area is the extension to more sophisticated promotional material such as video and/or CD-ROM production under a program they have called Totally Motivated Design. This is an exciting development which is attracting a lot of interest both locally and further afield.

Fourthly, their construction and property maintenance strand has provided valuable work experience and skill development for the young people as well as producing much needed maintenance for some local facilities and construction of valuable improvements such as the installation of disability ramps completed as a result of work with the Hawkesbury Access and Equity Forum Committee. Fifthly, their local arts project was an important feature within the rejuvenation of part of Richmond's central business district.

Hawkesbury Skills' success has been outstanding. Of the 208 participants in the previous and current Work for the Dole contracts, 54 per cent have gone on to further study or employment. At Hawkesbury Skills, they display a victory board which lists the names and the progress of people who have left Work for the Dole and gone on to further study or to employment. They have completed three full boards with names of successful graduates from their Work for the Dole program and are on their fourth board of people moving on to study, to full-time study or to employmentâthat is, over 100 people have achieved success out of Work for the Dole.

The wide range of occupations, study courses and the start of worthwhile careers shows a fascinating insight into the range of interests and the employment opportunities available and is a tribute to the hard work of the team at Hawkesbury Skills. Full credit goes to Graeme Skimmin, the former manager, Hugh McKinnon, the current manager, and the current team which brings with it ability, commitment and resourcefulnessâa team which is making a real difference in the lives of these young people, a team which is helping them to find hope, to find motivation and to find direction and which is helping them to make that very difficult transition from unemployment to work. I am pleased that the Work for the Dole program has been increased in the recent budget and I look forward to further valuable work in the Hawkesbury region as a result of this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI have consistently called on this government over a record four Customs ministers to address the issue of Port Kembla's lack of surveillance and the stress the five Customs officers covering Sutherland to the Victorian border are forced to work under. Australia, because of its lack of coordinated coastal surveillance, has become a popular destination for refugees and a money spinner for unscrupulous smugglers dealing in human cargo.

speech.para: Just yesterday came news that another 13 illegal immigrants had penetrated Australia's coastline in the west. This comes on top of the human cargo vessels that have plied the Australian coastline in the last month. It really has become a case of `another day, another boat'. With this year having hit its mid point, we have already seen a 122 per cent increase in illegal immigrants arriving on our shores. It will come as no surprise that there are more on the way.

Despite all this and despite the government having been warned, our coastal surveillance has been diminished rather than enhanced. It is seriously underfunded and seriously underresourced. The answer so far by the government has been the establishment of a prime ministerial task force, due to report findings by the end of this month. The Customs minister has now been saying publicly that the report deadline may have to be extended. What for? The minister already has a series of reports but she is determined not to release them publicly. The reason is that the reports will reveal that the government was warned to expect this plague of human cargo arrivals long ago.

While they were being warned, the government continued to penny pinch from our front-line coastal defence agencies. This is what will be revealed by the reports that the government refuses to publicly release. These reports reveal that no surveillance of major ports like Port Kembla has left communities absolutely vulnerable to the smuggling of drugs, people and contraband.

The message is out there in Asia, Africa and the Middle East that Australia's coastline is an easy touch. It is a message heard loud and clear by smugglers and the people with limited confidence in the future of their current homelands. Protecting Australia's territorial integrity does not come cheap, but this government does not appear to recognise that effective coastal surveillance cannot be achieved on the cheap either. You will need more than an aeroplane buzzing around the sky to ensure territorial integrity and need more than the five dedicated Customs officers undertaking their duties with one hand tied behind their backs to protect the community.

It is time for the government to forget about reports and instead act now to defend the coast against an ever increasing incursion of human cargo headed for Australia. While the government does nothing, it is leaving our coastlines vulnerable. There are boats even today off the top end of Queensland, and what is interesting is that the boats are now coming down the east coast rather than the west coast. They are still coming down the west coast, but they have added the east coast to their itinerary, and the fault lies with the government and its penny-pinching methods. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today in this House to speak out on an issue that I believe we as a society have to urgently addressâthat is, the criminal activities directed at one of the most vulnerable groups in our community, the aged. The latest figures from the Bureau of Criminology reveal an alarming rise in the incidence of crime against older citizens. It is something that all decent Australians find appalling and outrageous. Occasionally we see a story on the news about one of our senior citizens who fought off an attacker. We condemn the cowardice of the criminal and marvel at the tenacity of the older victim, as well we should. But, sadly, for every one of those high profile incidents there are thousands of victims who simply could not fight off the offender.

speech.para: In this the International Year of Older Persons I believe we need to look at new ways to help solve the growing problem. While police and sentencing are state government matters, I feel compelled to speak out on behalf of the thousands of older people I represent. This generation of seniors have earned our respect and admiration. Many fought in the Second World War. They worked hard to build Australia into the fantastic country it is today. They are very strong, tenacious individuals, but physicallyâsimply by virtue of their ageâmany are frail or just not as able as they once were. They do not deserve to spend their retirement either fearful or having to lock themselves in their homes with expensive and invasive security measures. They should not have to worry that someone will try to swindle them out of their life savings or snatch their handbag when they go shopping.

In my view, one part of the solution is to set in place much tougher sentences for those who commit crimes against people over 60 years of age. It is not the whole solution. I think as a society we have to reinstil values of decency and respect for our elderly. This starts in rebuilding family relationships and ensuring children have a loving family environment in which they can learn such values. However, I think we can start to tackle this problem. I am calling on all state governments to look at doubling the sentences given for a particular crime if it is carried out on someone over the age of 60. If someone was convicted of assault and would have normally received five years and that assault was carried out on someone over 60, then the sentence should be automatically doubled to 10 years.

Let us face it, people who prey on this age group are cowards. They figure they are going to get the same sentence if they try to mug a robust 25-year-old who might fight back or an 80-year-old, who physically has less chance of doing so. So they go for the easy option. But they may think twice if they know that they will get a much tougher sentence if caught targeting older people.

It is incumbent on all of us as law makers to look at ways of addressing the concerns of this generation. I have written to the Queensland state Attorney-General asking that he look into this option as a way of protecting our elderly. It will send a strong message to criminals that, as a society, we will not continue to tolerate their targeting of this age group. Tougher sentencing and, may I add, truth in sentencing is one way we can tackle the growing incidence of crime against our seniors. I call on the state governments, which are responsible for sentencing, to look into this matter with urgency and to take action to protect our elderly.

talk.start.para: âI raise today the lack of funding for Parents Anonymous, a service in Victoria which, after 25 years of service to the Victorian community, has now lost its funding. That funding was $100,000, which was provided by the state government in Victoria to provide detailed counselling services to parents who were in crisis. As a result of the funding being cut by the Victorian government, there is no phone counselling service available in Victoria for parents in crisis. There is a parent help line which the Victorian government has been telling us is the equivalent. However, that help line provides only referral services. It does not allow a mother or father in crisis to call and talk through with a trained counsellor the issues that they might be dealing with in such a way that they can handle those issues, rather than taking it out on their children if they have got to that point in their crisis.

speech.para: This service closed on 14 May this year, after 25 years of operating at the presbyterian church in Collins Street, Melbourne. Over 70 volunteers worked for this service. That is why a service could be provided from 7 a.m. until midnight on the small amount of $100,000. A large number of those volunteers live and work in my electorate. Certainly, a large number of the callers live in my electorate and have found this service to be of great value over the 25 years.

I am very concerned. The reason I raise this matter in this federal parliament is that Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services, said in the recent budget statements that the government have great concern for parenting issues and that a large amount of money should be put into educating parents and providing counselling and mediation. I would urge the minister to intervene in this matter and either encourage the Victorian government to reinstate the funding or provide the funding themselves so that Victorian parents are not disadvantaged compared to parents across the rest of the country.

In New South Wales and Queensland, Parent Line is funded to provide counselling services as well as advice and referral. In Victoria, the Kennett government has not seen fit to provide sufficient funding for those counselling services to be available immediately for parents at the time of their crisis. In recent times we have even seen a hotline set up for AFL footballers if they are having trouble dealing with drug and alcohol issues, dealing with family crisis or dealing with difficulties in being away from their family when they travel. AFL footballers can ring if they are experiencing any difficulties or are in crisis, but parents across Victoria do not have a similar service. I think $100,000 is not too much to ask this minister to intervene, and I would encourage her to do so.

talk.start.para: âThe arrest and conviction of Australian CARE workers Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace by Yugoslav authorities is appalling and almost beyond our understanding. The most charitable and forgiving interpretation of this miscarriage of justice is that it is a result of a misunderstanding of what these two fine Australians were doing.

speech.para: Peter Wallace's family live in Mackay in my electorate. The Wallace family are distinguished by their long-serving commitment to selfless public service and their community holds them in the very highest esteem. Their courage and fortitude during this terrible ordeal have been remarkable, for we can only imagine the pain they are enduring daily. My local newspaper in Mackay, the Daily Mercury, galvanised the feeling of outrage in the local community and organised a petition calling for the release of Peter Wallace and his colleague. The overwhelming response, 6,500 signatures, was a testimony to fine reputations so deservedly earned by the Wallace family. I circulated that petition to all members and senators and I want to thank those who so willing signed it. The response was tremendous and it gave heart and encouragement to Mr and Mrs Wallace.

Recently I presented that petition, with Mr and Mrs Wallace, to His Excellency the Yugoslav Ambassador to Australia. We were given a most courteous and sympathetic reception and I was impressed by the ambassador's obvious personal distress, not just as a representative of his country but as a parent who loves and cares about his own children. The ambassador is a man of culture, a celebrated poet in his country, and is keenly aware of the anguish of the families of our two CARE workers. I know that he would have conveyed that petition to his government in Belgrade with his personal observations.

I would now like to mention the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer. He has defended Peter Wallace's and Steve Pratt's innocence without indulging in intemperate remarks. Mr Downer's calm, compassionate and commonsense approach to this distressing matter has been a great comfort to the families, friends and supporters of Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt. I also want to thank the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, for their ongoing efforts to obtain the release of Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt. Mr Fischer and Mr Downer both met Mr and Mrs Wallace while they were here in Canberra and assured them that the government was leaving no stone unturned in the unrelenting campaign to have them freed.

The military court that convicted and sentenced Peter Wallace and Steve Pratt has until Friday to prove written reasons for the verdicts. An appeal will be lodged within three days and we must all hope and pray that that appeal meets with success. I notice that Mr Jesse Jackson is intervening and again we hope that he is successful in the moves he is making. I believe that the government has done and is doing all it can. I also want to thank the ongoing efforts of Mr Malcolm Fraser, the special envoy, CARE Australia and so many others, including the President of South Africa, Nelson Mandela, the UN Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, and the UN Human Rights Commissioner, Mary Robinson. I am sure our thoughts and prayers are with the families today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Hockey:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Tanner moved by way of amendment:

talk.start.para: âI rise to echo the remarks in the House of my friend and colleague the member for Melbourne, the shadow minister for finance. I indicate to the Main Committee, in my capacity as shadow minister for communications, that it is proposed when the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1999 reaches the Senate, the Labor Party will move for it to be referred to the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee to deal with that aspect of the bill that relates to radio spectrum. I simply make the point that there is no insidious motive in suggesting this reference.

speech.para: This bill cuts across radio spectrum and radio licences. It has been something of a practice in the past that where technical matters such as these cut across spectrum issues they do get the scrutiny of a committee. In recent times, we have seen radio telecommunications legislation so referred. It does give the industry the opportunity of commenting on the detail of the government's proposal with which, I must say, at first sight there seems to be no difficulty. I indicate that to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who is at the table, but I do not expect at the end of the day that will either delay the passage of the legislation or cause the government any great difficulty.

talk.start.para: âI would like to thank all participants in the debate on these measures. In conclusion, I would like to summarise the merits of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1999 . In addition, the bill will ensure that Australia is able to assert its taxing rights over income from the use of spectrum where the spectrum licence is owned by a non-resident and includes payments for the use of spectrum licences in the definition of royalty under the income tax law.

speech.para: Secondly, this bill will make a number of technical corrections to the tax law arising from the tax law improvement project. Thirdly, this bill will enable the calculation of the provisional tax uplift factor using the new single measure of gross domestic product as part of the change in the presentation of the national accounts published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Amendment negatived.

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 34, page 30 (lines 12 to 15), omit paragraph (b), substitute:

talk.start.para: âThe opposition will not be opposing the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 but will be seeking the support of the Main Committee for a second reading amendment that condemns the government's sloppy taxation administration in failing to act quickly to close a tax avoidance loophole which now requires transitional provisions.

speech.para: The bill has three main purposes. First, it amends the early release of superannuation provisions of the Small Superannuation Accounts Act 1995, which governs funds held in the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve to make them consistent with the early release provisions applying to other superannuation funds. Second, it amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to close a loophole which allows certain distributions of trust income to superannuation funds set up for the benefit of trust beneficiaries under non-arms-length arrangements to be taxed at a concessional rate of 15 per cent. Thirdly, it amends the superannuation guarantee regulations to continue, with effect from 1 August 1996, an exemption from the superannuation guarantee charge for employers who hire senior foreign executive employees who meet the criteria for former class 413 overseas executive visa. I will address each of these subjects in order.

The first provision of the legislation relates to applying the early release provisions to the SHAR. When Labor introduced the superannuation guarantee reforms, many workers who did not previously receive superannuation contributions became entitled to contributions made on their behalf by their employer. The success of the superannuation guarantee and Labor's other superannuation reforms is widely accepted. Superannuation coverage increased from around 40 per cent of the work force in the early 1980s to the current level of over 90 per cent of all employees. In particular, part-time and casual workers were also able to access the benefits of saving for a retirement income through a tax advantaged superannuation account. This included the wider benefits of death and disability insurance and a host of other services offered by superannuation funds. The coverage of women workers in particular increased dramatically.

Because part-time and casual employees became eligible for superannuation contributions, employers were required to contribute small amounts due to the smaller wages of these employees. Unfortunately, not all privately operated superannuation funds would accept small amounts and some employees may not have been able to find an appropriate superannuation fund that would receive small contributions. The Labor government responded to this policy challenge by creating the SHAR in 1995. The SHAR exists as a low cost, safe haven for employees' superannuation contributions which ensures that the contributions will not be eroded as a result of excessive fees and charges. Labor also introduced member protection rules applying to all superannuation funds that prevent the erosion of small balances, thus ensuring that workers' retirement incomes are preserved.

SHAR accounts have interest calculated on the daily balance of the account which is then credited to the account on a quarterly basis. The interest is exempt from income tax. Employees are encouraged to build their SHAR balances up and transfer them into a superannuation fund other than SHAR. However, if an account balance exceeds $1,200, interest is only credited on the first $1,200 of the balance, which also acts as an incentive for employees to transfer their funds to another fund which allows the retirement savings to compound.

Labor also recognised that some workers may need access to their superannuation savings before retirement in limited circumstances, such as in times of financial hardship as a result of being unemployed or being retrenched. That is why we introduced measures which allowed access to not only account balances in SHAR but also superannuation funds in general. When people are down on their luck, Labor's early access provision allowed limited access to superannuation generally by applying to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. An applicant was required to prove that they were suffering from financial hardship. Having proved that to the ISC, the applicant was then entitled to access some of their superannuation.

It was also possible to access superannuation accounts with less than $500 in them if they changed employers and also if a person was permanently leaving the country. In other words, if a person was no longer going to be a burden to the Australian taxpayer, they could access their superannuation contributions. The government changed the early release provisions of superannuation moneys with effect from 1 July 1998. The new provisions are: applicants suffering from severe financial hardship must meet an `objective test' of 26 continuous weeks on a Commonwealth income support payment if under 55, then prove to their superannuation trustees that they are suffering from financial hardship; if leaving an employer, the $500 threshold for receipt of monies was reduced to $200; and, if permanently leaving Australia, access is no longer available to those aged under 55.

The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation examined the regulations and recommended a similar although slightly less onerous set of criteria. Labor senators, seeking a practical solution to the government's policy, proposed that the objective test should be reduced to 12 weeks. While not being the ideal situation, at least it was a better deal for people suffering from financial hardship than the government's original position of 39 weeks on a Commonwealth income support payment. The final result was that the original 39 weeks on income support test was reduced to 26 weeks, the $500 threshold was reduced to a $200 threshold, and persons leaving Australia were allowed one year's grace period to sort our their affairs while still being able to access their superannuation. The bill provides the same provisions to the SHAR.

While Labor is not opposing these provisions in the bill, I wish to bring some issues to the attention of the government that it should consider closely. People should be encouraged to leave their superannuation funds in their account to compound so it is there at retirement to provide a decent retirement income. However, those in severe financial difficulty should be able to access small amounts of superannuation to get through a difficult period. The government has introduced provisions allowing access to superannuation on compassionate grounds through the APRA. The access conditions are strict and often people in financial difficulty do not meet those strict criteria.

For example, those who cannot pay their rent are not able to get access to their superannuation but those who have a housing mortgage may qualify for access if their mortgage is about to be foreclosed. There are cases where people will run up credit card debts to pay their mortgages but cannot access their super to pay off their credit card debt. Instead, this policy encourages them to use available funds to pay off their credit card debt but let the bank move to foreclose so that they can access their superannuation. That policy makes very little sense. Like many of my parliamentary colleagues, I am aware of people who have claimed to be in financial difficulty but who have had to wait the full 26 weeks before being able to apply for access to their superannuation funds. I suggest that the government might like to review the activities of this legislation and report to the parliament on how these provisions are working.

The second provision in the legislation relates to the closing of the tax loophole. Schedule 2 of the bill proposes to close a tax avoidance loophole, and this is welcomed by the opposition. Section 273 of the ITAA currently does not prevent the distribution of trust income to a superannuation entity set up for the benefit of the trust beneficiary. The income of a superannuation entity is generally taxed at the rate of 15 per cent if there is no `special income' component, which is usually taxed at the rate of 47 per cent. Special income is income derived from certain non-arms-length transactions that fall within the provisions of section 273, which are designed to prevent tax minimisation.

However, if certain non-arms-length income is distributed to a superannuation fund set up for the benefit of a trust beneficiary, it may be possible to have it taxed at the concessional rate of 15 per cent rather than 47 per cent. This bill is designed to close this loophole by ensuring that income derived from certain types of non-arms-length transactions that is distributed to a super fund from a trust will be treated as special income and will be taxed at the rate of 47 per cent. While this measure is welcome, the government is guilty of sloppy administration by having to retrospectively apply this measure. Let me showcase this example of poor tax administration for the benefit of the Main Committee.

In November 1997, the Assistant Treasurer issued a press release announcing the closure of the loophole. Although this was a case of government by press release, it was a warning that a loophole would be closed and that was a welcome announcement. However, the original bill giving effect to the announced measures was not introduced until some seven months later, in July 1998. The bill concerned, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1998, lapsed when the election was called by the Prime Minister.

If this was not bad enough, the measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1998 and in the bill currently before us were different from those announced in the press release of November 1997. That means that those people who acted in good faith on the government's press release of November 1997 could, in some circumstances, now be in breach of the bill currently before the Main Committee. Fortunately, the government addressed this issue by including transitional provisions for unit holders who derived income complying with the November press release that would have been in breach of the bill. The point is that these transitional issues should not be necessary. It is a very good example of worst practice tax administration. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"while not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for sloppy taxation administration by delaying the closure of a tax avoidance loophole and being forced to introduce retrospective legislation and transitional provisions".

Of course we are used to sloppy taxation administration from this government. The Treasurer has been unable or unwilling to answer simple questions relating to the GST on food in the House this week, for example. We should not forget the government's record on the superannuation surcharge, which has caused and continues to cause enormous problems for the administrators and members of superannuation funds. However, one would have thought that, given this measure is supposed to prevent the loss of some $15 million in revenue, the government would have given it a policy priority rather than waiting over a year and a half to implement it.

The third provision of the legislation relates to the continuation of the superannuation guarantee exemption for employers of foreign executives. The final schedule of this bill makes amendments to the superannuation guarantee exemption on foreign executives. From August 1996, new visa classes 456 and 457 were introduced which replaced the visa class 413 applying to senior executives visiting Australia. Visa class 413 was recognised in the SG regulations as exempting employers who employ senior executives who make provisions for their retirement in their country of origin. However, the SG regulations do not exempt employers with executives employed under the new visa classes from the SG charge.

This measure continues the exemption for employers under the old 413 visa class and extends the exemption for 456 and 457 visa class holders. A question arises as to whether, although they are exempted from having to pay the superannuation guarantee contributions on behalf of their employees, those employees can salary sacrifice into superannuation to gain access to tax concessions, as has happened in the past. However, the provisions restricting access to superannuation moneys after leaving Australia permanently until age 55 are expected to prevent this practice from continuing. That concludes my observations about the legislation.

talk.start.para: âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.
âI am advised the government will not be accepting the amendment by the honourable member for Melbourne.
âYou amaze me!

âI thought I might have surprised you. Nevertheless, the amendment he has moved is obviously completely unsuitable to the government's purposes in the Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 , which is submitted for consideration in the Main Committee today. I want to make a couple of comments about the member for Melbourne's contribution, some general comments about superannuation and a couple of specific comments about the bill in my contribution in this place today.

speech.para: Administration by press release, as I think the member for Melbourne put it, is standard practice. In relation to taxation mattersâmatters which affect the way in which income for the government is collected from Australian citizens and companies operating in this countryâthe practice has been a matter of usual course for a long period of time, and I cannot see how it can be done any other way. When rules change, the announcement of the change in itself signals essentially the change in the rules, and legislation always follows. This is a practice which was used by the Labor Party when in power, it is a practice which makes sense and the government will continue to use it. Just as budget announcements on the second Tuesday in May have always produced a series of immediate changes to taxation rules, so too did the press release of 17 November 1997 which announced various changes to tighten rules governing access to moneys in those small superannuation holding accounts reserve funds.

In the general sense, changes to superannuation I do not really like. I think people expect greater certainty, and they lose faith with superannuation each and every time a change is wrought to the system governing superannuation. I know that in 1996 I was elected, in part, on the platform of there being no more changes to superâcertainly not following the processes which the Australian Labor Party followed during their 13 years in power with introducing laws, amending them, changing people's expectations and changing people's operating parameters, all of these uncertainties having been built into the superannuation system in this country by the Australian Labor Party.

In this regard, I acknowledge the government's 15 per cent superannuation surcharge. It was not voted against by anybody in either House, as I understand it, but I think just about everybody in this place would hope it disappears one day. We all accept the 15 per cent superannuation surcharge was brought in as one of the many measures behind the government's determination to overturn the $10.5 billion Beazley black hole which we found when we came to power. That an amount of $23 billion was added to the government debt in the last two Labor budgets in this country is a matter of history, and the 15 per cent surcharge was one of the measures introduced by this government to overturn the debt and create a surplus inside three years. Whilst I would like this surcharge to disappear down a black hole in itself because I think it sends the wrong signal to people who should be encouraged to put money aside for their retirement years, I accept it was a measure made necessary because of the economic conditions the Labor Party left this government with.

Superannuation should be all about encouraging thrift, encouraging saving and encouraging people to put something aside for their retirement years. I suspect I am of a generationâin fact, I know I am of a generationâwhich is constantly being told I will not access a pension from the government. Rather, my superannuation contributions will be the basis on which I should retire one day about 40 years from now. I guess this is in stark contrast to a lot of older Australians who had an expectation built out of measures introduced by governments earlier this century of there being a universal pension. In fact, for many years in this country a percentage of the tax taken was a contribution to a universal pension scheme. A lot of Australians continually argue with me that, having made their contribution through the tax system, they should be entitled to a retirement income. Theirs is an understandable sentiment, it is one which I support in general terms and it encourages me to aspire to making sure I have sufficient income to look after myself and those I care about in my retirement years.

Superannuation should also be about, therefore, rewarding effort. For those who have bothered to do something for themselves instead of waiting for their nation to pick up the tab of their retirement years, superannuation should ensure they be rewarded for their effort. They should be given stability in rules and regulations which govern both the money going in and the money coming out. They should be able to plan with some certainty that their expectations will be met.

A very wise and, in fact, quite wealthy manâI knew him about 20 years agoâsaid to me when I first entered the work force, `Don't take out superannuation until you're about 10 or 15 years shy of retiring because the value of money changes.' This was an understandable comment in that high inflation era. I guess one of the best things this government has been able to achieve is a low inflation environment, which means people taking out superannuation today can now set a benchmark for the performance of future governments to meet: to keep inflation low, to keep interest rates low and to keep the economy stable so as to ensure the expectations they have as they contribute to superannuation are met.

The Australian Labor Party's compulsory levyâwhich has meant every worker in this country has forgone a wage rise over quite a number of years now in order to make sure of their having money put into a superannuation accountâhas had a great deal of success because of its compulsory nature. The member for Melbourne commented that we have gone from a 40 per cent superannuation contribution pool amongst Australia's work force to well over 90 per cent. Naturally, because it is a compulsory contribution. But, again, a number of people have made the comment to me that their wage increases were traded off by the people who ran the unions and Industrial Relations Commission hearings year in and year out; a compulsory superannuation was taken away from people's expectation of a certain level of earnings in order to ensure there was a compulsory saving for retirement.

The fact of the matter is every small business in this country is still meeting the cost of that wage rise without actually giving the incentive to the worker on a weekly basis of the benefit of that wage rise. The compulsory superannuation levy is a wage rise forgone. There is no reward to the worker on an every-day week. In fact, in a lot of ways, the Australian Labor Party have sent a signal of devaluing Australian workers as a result of this deal.

My cynicism extends to another extent: superannuation funds administered by union officials of course have done very well as a result of the system the Australian Labor Party established. Union superannuation funds management fees which they rake off each year now contribute towards the cost of the Australian Labor Party's election campaigns. Workers in this country have their savings locked away in superannuation funds and, as some of the measures in the bill before us today dictate, it is very difficult for them to meet the criteria which may be applied in order for them to access funds because of compassionate reasons.

A lot of people would like to have access to the money which they have had to give up through a compulsory levyâto pay off bills, to perhaps get rid of certain personal credit costs, or to lower personal debt. They have not had the benefit of accessing increases from their boss in the form of wage rises because they are forgone as a compulsory super charge. They cannot direct these funds directly to paying off personal debt.

It is an absolute irony that the national debt and each person's personal debt in this country have gone up while, at the same time, compulsory savings have produced an increase in the overall savings in this country. So it is an interesting point to make: we have this amazing irony that, yes, savings through the compulsory superannuation levy are up, but debt is also increasing. At the same time individual Australians would like to be able to access some of the money to repay their own personal debtâand I think this would be a very good thing. But understandably, because of the overall objectives of superannuation which are now clearly understood by a lot of people, it is difficult for them to access those funds.

I suspect in a lot of ways the jury is out on superannuation and a lot of people remain somewhat sceptical, particularly as changes continue to come in. As a government, we have had to continue to deal with a number of necessary changes in order to fix up things which were left unfixed by Labor's rush into super. Those necessary changes include those matters before us today.

There is the matter of small amounts held in the superannuation holdings account reserve. This was a response from the Labor government after it became pretty obvious to a lot of people that, for a long period of time, small amounts of super were being milked dry by management fees and people were losing their wages into superannuation accounts to have management fees drawn off them; in fact, the total amount of benefit they were getting was becoming zero at a rate of knots. This was fixed back in about 1995 by the Small Superannuation Accounts Act.
